articles.headline: In Surprise Move, Fed Signals Pivot to Normal Policy
articles.snippet: The increase in the discount rate is seen as a first step by the Fed to normalize lending after more than two years of extraordinary actions to prop up the economy.
articles.abstract: The increase in the discount rate is seen as a first step by the Fed to normalize lending after more than two years of extraordinary actions to prop up the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Taking a step to normalize lending after holding interest rates to extraordinary lows for more than a year to prop up the financial system, the Federal Reserve on Thursday raised the interest rate it charges on short-term loans to banks.

articles.headline: Revenue Rose but Profit Dropped for Dell
articles.snippet: Dell executives hope that the end of the economic downturn will result in a resurgence in technology spending.
articles.abstract: Dell executives hope that the end of the economic downturn will result in a resurgence in technology spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: Still struggling to keep up with its competitors, Dell said on Thursday that its profit fell 5 percent in the fourth quarter, breaking with what has been a strong earnings season for technology companies.

articles.headline: 2 China Schools Said to Be Tied to Online Attacks
articles.snippet: Experts traced attacks on Google and other corporations to two schools in China, including one with military ties.
articles.abstract: Experts traced attacks on Google and other corporations to two schools in China, including one with military ties.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  A series of online attacks on Google and dozens of other American corporations have been traced to computers at two educational institutions in China, including one with close ties to the Chinese military, say people involved in the investigation.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and David Barboza

articles.headline: Equality at Issue for MBIA
articles.snippet: Two lawsuits against the insurer MBIA are pending. If the company prevails, investors who now own bonds insured by MBIA will have a greater margin of safety.
articles.abstract: Two lawsuits against the insurer MBIA are pending. If the company prevails, investors who now own bonds insured by MBIA will have a greater margin of safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: All insurance policyholders are equal. But some are more equal than others.

articles.headline: Coded to Obey Law, Lights Become Marlboro Gold
articles.snippet: Tobacco companies plan to use light packaging to identify “light” cigarettes, which critics say skirts the law.
articles.abstract: Tobacco companies plan to use light packaging to identify “light” cigarettes, which critics say skirts the law.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to new rules for marketing so-called light cigarettes, tobacco companies plan to honor the letter of the law  but to shade the truth, critics say.

articles.headline: Fed Move May Signal End to Easy Bank Profits
articles.snippet: The largely technical change in policy signals that the threat of a collapse in financial markets — so real just a year and a half ago — has dissipated.
articles.abstract: The largely technical change in policy signals that the threat of a collapse in financial markets — so real just a year and a half ago — has dissipated.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve to Wall Street: The days of easy money  and, just maybe, easy profits  are numbered.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Eric Dash

articles.headline: In Pakistan Raid, Taliban Chief Was an Extra Prize
articles.snippet: The capture of Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, the Afghan Taliban’s top military commander, was a “lucky accident,” an American official said.
articles.abstract: The capture of Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, the Afghan Taliban’s top military commander, was a “lucky accident,” an American official said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Pakistani security officers raided a house outside Karachi in late January, they had no idea that they had just made their most important capture in years.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Bleak Economy Pushing Health Insurers to Raise Rates, Analysts Say
articles.snippet: Though health insurers have come under attack by Washington for raising rates, the weak economy and rising cost of medical care may leave them little choice.
articles.abstract: Though health insurers have come under attack by Washington for raising rates, the weak economy and rising cost of medical care may leave them little choice.
articles.lead_paragraph: Health insurers lately seem more afraid of Wall Street than of Washington.

articles.headline: States Consider Medicaid Cuts as Use Grows
articles.snippet: Relentless fiscal pressure is driving the potential cuts, even as Democrats push to add 15 million to the rolls.
articles.abstract: Relentless fiscal pressure is driving the potential cuts, even as Democrats push to add 15 million to the rolls.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Facing relentless fiscal pressure and exploding demand for government health care, virtually every state is making or considering substantial cuts in Medicaid, even as Democrats push to add 15 million people to the rolls.
articles.byline: By Kevin Sack and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Fewer People Late Paying Mortgage
articles.snippet: Mortgage Bankers called the fourth quarter a crucial turning point for housing. Still, the percentage of loans in foreclosure rose.
articles.abstract: Mortgage Bankers called the fourth quarter a crucial turning point for housing. Still, the percentage of loans in foreclosure rose.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as the Obama administration stepped up efforts to aid homeowners facing foreclosure, data released Friday indicated that the housing crisis might finally have stopped getting worse.
